questions.question: What is Agile software development?
options: An iterative approach emphasizing flexibility, collaboration, and customer feedback
questions.explanation: Agile is an iterative software development approach that emphasizes flexibility, collaboration, continuous improvement, and rapid delivery. It values responding to change over following a fixed plan.

questions.question: What are the four core values of the Agile Manifesto?
options: Individuals and interactions, Working software, Customer collaboration, Responding to change
Documentation, Planning, Contracts, Following a plan
questions.explanation: The Agile Manifesto values: 1) Individuals and interactions over processes and tools, 2) Working software over comprehensive documentation, 3) Customer collaboration over contract negotiation, 4) Responding to change over following a plan.

questions.question: What is Scrum?
options: An Agile framework using sprints, roles (Scrum Master, Product Owner, Team), and ceremonies
questions.explanation: Scrum is a popular Agile framework that organizes work into fixed-length iterations called sprints, with defined roles (Scrum Master, Product Owner, Development Team) and ceremonies (Sprint Planning, Daily Standup, Sprint Review, Retrospective).

questions.question: What is a sprint in Scrum?
options: A time-boxed iteration (typically 1-4 weeks) to complete a set of work
questions.explanation: A sprint is a time-boxed iteration in Scrum, typically lasting 1-4 weeks, during which a potentially shippable product increment is created. Each sprint has a goal and delivers working software.

questions.question: What is a Product Backlog?
options: An ordered list of all features, enhancements, and fixes needed for the product
questions.explanation: The Product Backlog is a prioritized list of all work items (user stories, features, bugs, technical debt) for the product. The Product Owner maintains and prioritizes it based on business value.

questions.question: What is a User Story?
options: A short description of a feature from the user's perspective
questions.explanation: A User Story is a simple description of a feature from an end-user perspective, typically in the format: 'As a [user], I want [goal] so that [benefit]'. It focuses on user value rather than technical details.

questions.question: What is a Daily Standup (Daily Scrum)?
options: A short daily meeting where team members share progress, plans, and blockers
questions.explanation: The Daily Standup is a brief 15-minute daily meeting where team members answer: What did I do yesterday? What will I do today? What blockers do I have? It promotes transparency and quick problem-solving.

questions.question: What is Kanban?
options: An Agile method using visual boards to manage workflow and limit work in progress
questions.explanation: Kanban is an Agile method that visualizes workflow on a board with columns (e.g., To Do, In Progress, Done) and limits work in progress (WIP) to improve flow and identify bottlenecks. It emphasizes continuous delivery.

questions.question: What is a Sprint Retrospective?
options: A meeting at the end of a sprint to reflect on process and identify improvements
questions.explanation: The Sprint Retrospective is held at the end of each sprint for the team to reflect on what went well, what didn't, and identify actionable improvements for the next sprint. It promotes continuous improvement.

questions.question: What is Continuous Integration (CI) in Agile?
options: Frequently merging code changes and automatically testing them
questions.explanation: Continuous Integration is a practice where developers frequently merge code changes into a shared repository, triggering automated builds and tests. This catches integration issues early and ensures the codebase stays stable.
